list.title: POPPING THE HOOD: The Grime Behind the Genius
list.description:
Everyone is obsessed with the "shiny red car"—the AI Model. We chase parameters and context windows, fighting to get into the driver's seat. But nobody is asking the most dangerous question: "Is the track safe?" When you put a $15 million machine on a broken track, it doesn’t just stop—it crashes.

AI isn't magic; it's a high-maintenance machine. In this session, we pop the hood to reveal the grime behind the genius. We will leave the "driver obsession" behind and look at the infrastructure required to actually finish the race.

Key Takeaways:

- **The Infrastructure Gap:** Why building 2025 AI on 2015 infrastructure is a guaranteed failure.
- **The Need for Speed:** Why CPUs are just "city streets," GPUs are "highways," and why we need the frictionless "hyperloop" of TPUs to handle modern complexity.
- **The New Threat Vector:** How attacks have shifted from data theft to prompt injection, and why you need "Model Armor" to protect the reasoning mind of your AI.

Stop just driving. Come learn how to build the track.

list.title: Build Your First AI Agent with Google ADK
list.description: Learn to build intelligent AI agents using Google's Agent Development Kit (ADK). In this hands-on workshop, you'll create a custom agent using free-tier resources. We'll walk through crafting agent instructions, understanding function-calling capabilities, testing locally with the playground, and exploring how agents reason and make decisions. You'll work with a starter repository that you can fork and customize for your own projects. Bring your laptop with Python installed and be ready to experiment!

list.title: An incursion into the intriguing world of AI infrastructure
list.description: Environmental and social aspects of AI infrastructure. Exploring the often-overlooked impacts of the physical systems that power modern intelligence.

list.title: How to start building a game and overcome daily challenges
list.description: Curious about making your first game? This session walks you through getting started with a game engine, learning through tutorials and game jams, and using AI to speed up your workflow. Discover how to shape your game loop, design for your audience, and fill your world with assets - whether self-made, sourced, or AI-assisted. Finally, learn how to build your visibility through social media, influencers, and the right release platforms to bring your creation to life.

list.title: The Human Edge: Soft Skills in the Age of AI
list.description:
As artificial intelligence reshapes industries and automates routine tasks, leaders face a fundamental question: What kind of world of work do we want to create? For centuries, humans were expected to work like machines. Now, in the age of AI, humans can focus on what only they can do while machines handle the rest.While AI excels at data processing and efficiency, it cannot replicate uniquely human abilities like nuanced judgment, empathy, relationship-building, and ethical decision-making. The future belongs to those who bring these distinctly human strengths to the table. 
 The Human Edge explores why human skills such as emotional intelligence, critical thinking, influence, and collaboration are essential for future-ready leaders and teams. This session highlights psychological safety as the cultural foundation that enables these skills to thrive, helping teams unlock their full potential and succeed in a rapidly evolving world.

list.title: What Models Can See: Inside Modern Computer Vision
list.description: Discover how modern vision models can detect objects without ever being trained on them. In this hands-on workshop, we will explore the evolution from traditional object detection to zero-shot models like Grounding DINO, which understand natural language prompts to identify anything you can describe. After a short theory session, we’ll dive into a practical Google Colab session where the attendees will experiment with detecting custom objects using only text descriptions (no training data required). By the end, they will understand both the power and limitations of these models, and leave with practical skills to apply them to their own projects in research, industry, or creative applications.

list.title: The Tech Talent Barrier Lab
list.description:
An interactive data-driven session sharing documented barriers to tech employment. Industry leaders respond with concrete actionable solutions. 
 What happens when you combine real pilot data with live problem-solving? 
 Join us as participants from our 7-week Career camp share documented barriers to tech employment. Industry leaders respond with concrete actionable solutions. And even everything gets documented real-time. 
 This isn't a typical panel. It's a collaborative experiment in making hiring systems accountable. 
 Who should attend:
 	 Anyone involved in tech hiring 
	 Women navigating career transitions 
	 People curious about data-driven inclusion

list.title: Punk strategies to find your voice!
list.description: Punk culture, in its political function, stands against the fundamentals of capitalism: anti-consumerism, nonconformity, anti-racism, anti-sexism, and anti-discrimination of all kinds. Appropriation, hacktivism, and culture jamming are among the consistently effective strategies associated with subcultures. We will explore, through examples and case studies, how to remain passionate and relevant by using punk tactics to develop one's voice and maintain a critical perspective.

list.title: Project Management Tools
list.description: Defining requirements goes beyond SMART goals. This talk demonstrates simple tools to define, organize, and prioritize requirements effectively (Eisenhower matrix, SWOT, MoSCoW, INVEST/AQUSA).

list.title: Beyond the Pixel
list.description: Let's create a dialogue between digital and physical communication media. Group exploration of imaginary digital tool designs meeting social needs. Brainstorming, interface design, interaction principles.

list.title: Gamification in the service of science
list.description:
Gamification and serious games are now powerful tools for making science more accessible, engaging, and understandable for both expert and non-specialist audiences. Beyond entertainment, these approaches leverage mechanisms from cognitive psychology, UX, and game design to support learning, motivation, and participation. 
 This conference will offer a critical perspective on gamification applied to scientific and educational contexts, through concrete examples of research projects, educational platforms, and interactive tools. It will address the conditions for success, pitfalls to avoid, and ethical issues related to the use of games in serious contexts.

list.title: From Theory to Practice: Reinforcement Learning in Video Games
list.description:
Reinforcement learning (RL) is a powerful paradigm for training intelligent agents through interaction with their environment, yet its adoption in the video game industry remains limited. This presentation proposes a pragmatic, production-oriented approach to applying reinforcement learning to video games, illustrated through concrete examples in Unreal Engine. 
 The session begins with a high-level overview of the core principles of reinforcement learning (agent, environment, state, action, reward, and policy), providing insight into why RL is particularly well suited to interactive and dynamic systems such as games. It then focuses on the integration of reinforcement learning into Unreal Engine, covering architectural choices, data exchange with machine learning frameworks, and key practical challenges. 
 Finally, the presentation explores the use of reinforcement learning for automated video game testing, where RL-driven agents can explore environments, test game mechanics, and detect edge cases at scale. The goal is to demonstrate how reinforcement learning can evolve from research into a practical tool for game development and quality assurance.

list.title: Break It Before They Do - Threat Modeling at Startup Speed
list.description: The internet is adversarial by default and the threat landscape is changing day by day.  In this talk, I'll present current security trends and some real-world breach examples of the technical threats they pose.  Then we'll flip the script with a live threat modeling exercise that demonstrates how to turn security threats into concrete controls.  Because the most powerful builders aren't just innovative, they're adversarial thinkers.
